td.p: Thomson, John. Journal, Mackenzie River, 1800-1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0021

div.p: Sunday the 8th[.] In the morning the Indians went away.
Monday the 9th[.] Martin made a Chair[.]

Thursday the 12th[.] Set St André to work about cutting his share of wood[.] [T]he Hunters at last arrived[,] they brought 60 hares, they complain that the late cold weather prevented them from coming sooner[.] Martin busy making Wedges[.]
Saturday the 14th[.] Martin made 62 Wedges to press Packs[.]

Monday the 16th[.] Fine weather[.] St André finished cutting 4 cords of wood. Martin & Plante hauled the same to the Door for which he promises to pay them 24 livres & as he finds himself too Lazy to cut the remaining Two Cords he gives Martin 13 Livres more to cut the same[.] In the afternoon we were very much surprised by the arrival of Laviolette Sick on a Train Two Indians having hauled him from their Lodges here[,] gave them Drams &c[.] Laviolette says that it is now near a Month since he can scarcely stand upon his Legs – his Body & Legs are very much swelled – he complains greatly that the Indians did not take proper care of him &c – gave the young Men a scolding for their Behavior – but they contradicted every word & insisted upon it that they took good care of him &c[.] Laviolette says that all these Indians have yet made but very few skins, as they employ most of their Time eating their Caches of Meat &c – besides the wolves & Carcajous make great Havoc amongst their Pichou Collets[.] On their way here they passed by a cache only 2 days march from here, containing 2 orignals all in Dry Meat[.] I just now told the Indian to whom it belongs that he must go tomorrow with a Couple of Men for the said Cache – but he would not any consideration consent & behaved so Insolently that I gave him a Twig of the Nose to teach him better Manners[.] All the Indians of this quarter are certainly a most Hatefull set, for Altho they all have caches of Meat in abundance – Yet it is impossible
